definition: a concept that measures the randomness, disorder, or uncertainty in a system, also defined as the amount of thermal energy unavailable to do work
notes: central to the second law of thermodynamics, which states that the entropy of an isolated system never decreases over time, meaning that systems naturally evolve toward a state of maximum disorder or equilibrium

definition: a network of connected things and people, all of which share data about the way they are used and their environments
excessive richness of nutrients in a lake or other body of water, frequently due to run-off from the land, which causes a dense growth of plant life

causes.name: agricultural runoff
causes.discussion: fertilizers containing nitrogen and phosphorus are washed into waterways

causes.name: sewage and septic systems
causes.discussion: discharge of wastewater can be high in nutrients

causes.name: industrial waste
causes.discussion: some industrial processes release nutrient-rich waste

causes.name: animal waste
causes.discussion: runoff from farms containing animal waste adds to the nutrient load

definition: rapid growth of algae and aquatic plants, which block sunlight from reaching lower plants
notes: when these blooms decompose, bacteria consume the available oxygen, creating hypoxic or "dead" zones where fish and other aquatic life cannot survive

definition: a semi-liquid mixture, typically of fine particles of manure, cement, or coal suspended in water

name: Javons Paradox
description: technological advancements increasing the efficiency of a resource can lead to an overall increase in its consumption, rather than a decrease (rebound effect)
explanation: the resource becomes cheaper to use, leading to higher demand that can outpace the efficiency gains, resulting in more total consumption
examples: more efficient engines made coal cheaper to use, which led to coal being used in more industries and ultimately increased overall coal consumption
more fuel-efficient cars lead to people driving more miles, increasing total fuel use
better cybersecurity incentivates taking more risks, which could result in more breaches
improvements in computing efficiency lead to proportional increases in demand for computing resources, ultimately balancing out the gains
the more roads are built, the more people will drive, which could actually worsen congestion
notes: the paradox occurs when this increased demand, driven by affordability, completely offsets or even exceeds the savings from the initial efficiency improvement

etymology: a portmanteau of consumer and proletariat
definition: a new underclass whose main activity is consumption, regulated from above
description: kept occupied with private problems, its desires provoked with the use of advertisements and its active participation limited to things like product choice, product customization, engaging with interactive products and life-style choice

definition: the process where a single, homogeneous mixture separates into two or more distinct, physically separate phases
notes: this phenomenon is often induced through quenching
historically, phase separation in glass was an unwanted defect, today, it is a controlled process used to create advanced materials

definition: in a directed acyclical graph (DAG), a traversal such that each node v is visited only after all its dependencies are visited
instances: scheduling a sequence of jobs or tasks based on their dependencies
determining the order of compilation tasks to perform in makefiles

definition: on a set, whenever for each pair of elements a,b, either a < b, or a == b, or a > b
notes: this is tantamount to saying that all elements are comparable

definition: said about a mapping, whenever no element is mapped to itself

instances.name: set inclusion
instances.discussion: if set A is strictly included in set B, then they must be different

instances.name: comparisons
instances.discussion: a comparison, such as < ("less than"), is said to be strict if for all elements, no E < E

definition: on a set, given any two elements x and y, x is never ordered before itself (strict), and x and y might be tied (neither x nor y may be ordered before the other, i.e. partial)

instances.name: books
instances.discussion: often enough a reader is persuaded that a book A is better than book B, yet uncertain as to whether B is better than, say, book C

instances.name: people
instances.discussion: for any two people A and B, sometimes it is clear to somebody that A is kinder (or wiser, or fitter) than B, sometimes it isn't clear at all

definition: a restricted version of a strict partial order: if x is tied with y, and y is tied with z, x is also tied with z

instances.name: time
instances.discussion: events that are equivalent in a given timeframe happen at the same time

instances.name: price
instances.discussion: an item may cost the same as another, but it can also cost the same amount of money

definition: the creative reuse of waste or unwanted products to create new items of higher quality and value
notes: unlike conventional recycling, which breaks down materials into raw components, upcycling involves transforming an item without destroying its original material integrity

definition: an extract prepared by dissolving an essential oil in alcohol of the proper strength, and adding water

title: Use Edges and Value the Marginal
contents: Edges occur where two systems meet – think ecosystems, cultures, etc. At these meeting points, diversity increases as the elements of both systems converge and create entirely new elements that may not exist otherwise.

definition: computer programs and other technology used to support or enable banking and financial services
discussion: Fintech, a blend of "financial" and "technology," refers to the use of technology to deliver financial services and products in new ways. It encompasses a wide range of innovations, from mobile banking apps and digital payments to blockchain, artificial intelligence, and algorithmic trading. Essentially, it's technology-enabled innovation that changes how consumers and businesses access and manage their finances.

name: humanists
description: Humanists are non-religious people who do not believe in a god. They believe that the world is a natural place, that human beings have natural origins, and that this is the one life we have. They believe it is possible to lead a good, happy, and meaningful life without religion.

Humanists recognise that we have many different natural capacities and believe we have a responsibility to make the most of them to build a fairer and kinder society. We can ask and answer questions about the world around us. We can use empathy and imagination to consider how other people might feel, and think about how to treat them well. We can make choices about how we want to live and take action to improve our own lives and the lives of others. Humanists believe we should think about the consequences of our actions on other people and animals and try to promote happiness and wellbeing. They celebrate these human capacities and the way different people have used them to make the world a better place.

definition: major life zone
a symbiotic association of a fungus and algae

description: composed primarily of cone-bearing needle-leaved or scale-leaved evergreen trees
found in northern circumpolar forested regions characterized by long winters and moderate to high annual precipitation

regions.name: closed-canopy forest
description: the southernmost portion of the taiga
contains the greatest richness of species, the warmest soils, the highest productivity, and the longest growing season within the boreal zone

regions.name: lichen woodland
description: a smaller parallel zone of sparse forest or woodland
tree crowns do not form a closed canopy
lichen mats and tundralike vegetation make up a significant portion of the ground cover

regions.name: forest-tundra
description: along the northern edge of tree growth (tree line)
patches of trees consisting of only a few species dot restricted portions of the landscape, forming a complex mosaic with tundra

many trees in the forest-tundra zone have never been known to produce viable seeds or have done so only sporadically. These trees were established during warmer climatic episodes from a few hundred to a few thousand years ago and have persisted since, usually by vegetative (asexual) reproduction

notes: occupies about 17 percent of Earth’s land surface area in a circumpolar belt of the far Northern Hemisphere
northward beyond, the taiga merges into the circumpolar tundra
plants and animals in the taiga are adapted to short growing seasons of long days that vary from cool to warm
hosts a limited number of conifer species—i.e., pine (Pinus), spruce (Picea), larch (Larix), fir (Abies)—and to a lesser degree by some deciduous genera such as birch (Betula) and poplar (Populus)
during winter a snowpack persists for at least five months in the southern portion of the taiga biome and for seven or eight months in the northern reaches
it has been estimated that Earth would be significantly colder without the taiga
areas with a mean annual temperature below freezing are susceptible to the formation of permafrost soils

discussion: an example is meant for illustrating or clarifying a point

saying: If opportunity doesn't knock, build a door
meaning: One should not passively wait for opportunities to arise, but rather actively create them. It encourages taking initiative and being proactive in pursuing one's goals. This can involve developing skills, networking, and taking calculated risks. Ultimately, it's about taking control of one's destiny and not relying solely on chance.

definition: a mapping of a set into a subset of its
a theoretical passage or "tunnel" through space-time that could create shortcuts for long journeys across the universe
notes: predicted by the theory of general relativity

definition: an example or pattern; esp. an outstandingly clear or typical example
the state of being normal, usual, or expected; a return to a previous, familiar, and generally accepted condition, often after a period of disruption or abnormality

name: ASML
definition: a Dutch multinational corporation that designs and manufactures photolithography systems used in the production of integrated circuits; a leading supplier to the semiconductor industry and the sole supplier of extreme ultraviolet (EUV) lithography machines

name: agar
definition: a jelly-like substance consisting of polysaccharides obtained from the cell walls of some species of red algae, primarily from the Gracilaria genus (Irish moss, ogonori) and the Gelidiaceae family (tengusa)
description: as found in nature, agar is a mixture of two components, the linear polysaccharide agarose and a heterogeneous mixture of smaller molecules called agaropectin

definition: a subgenre of science fiction in a dystopian futuristic setting said to focus on a combination of "low-life and high tech"; it features futuristic technological and scientific achievements, such as artificial intelligence and cyberware, juxtaposed with societal collapse, dystopia or decay
a hypothetical construction – usually a weapon or weapons system – which could destroy all life on a planet, particularly Earth, or destroy the planet itself
notes: Most hypothetical constructions rely on hydrogen bombs being made arbitrarily large, assuming there are no concerns about delivering them to a target (see Teller–Ulam design) or that they can be "salted" with materials designed to create long-lasting and hazardous fallout (e.g., a cobalt bomb)

definition: our tendency to cast people and groups in irreconcilable terms

notes: translates poorly to idiomatic Spanish
instances: Spain has more on the order of 100,000 laws

definition: the process of discovering and developing ideas, arguments, and evidence to support a particular claim or position
a measure of the disorder or randomness of a system

name: Silent Spring
author: Rachel Carson
topic: the extent of environmental damage caused by insecticides

definition: a system of methods used in a particular area of study or activity
an artistic and social movement that originated in Italy, and to a lesser extent in other countries, in the early 20th century
values: objects such as the car, the airplane, and the industrial city
notes: Many Italian Futurists supported Fascism in the hope of modernizing a country divided between the industrialising north and the rural, archaic South.
Like the Fascists, the Futurists were Italian nationalists, laborers, disgruntled war veterans, radicals, admirers of violence, and opposed to parliamentary democracy

definition: ten thousand hours is the average number of hours across disciplines that research shows it takes to become an expert
notes: based on research by Anders Ericsson
popularized in Malcolm Gladwell’s book Outliers

definition: a concept that views the universe, including human beings, as systems processing data; it assumes that the value of everything is determined by its contribution to data processing; it sees data as the fundamental organizing principle of reality, with information flows as the primary driver of progress and understanding
notes: it originates in the emerging significance of big data

the term has been expanded to describe what historian Yuval Noah Harari, in his book Homo Deus: A Brief History of Tomorrow from 2015, calls an emerging ideology or even a new form of religion, in which "information flow" is the "supreme value"

definition: the widespread collection and commodification of personal data by corporations
notes: surveillance capitalism is considered distinct from government surveillance, although the two can be mutually reinforcing

definition: the study of cyclic and seasonal natural phenomena, especially in relation to climate and plant and animal life

a philosophical and intellectual movement that advocates the enhancement of the human condition by developing and making widely available new and future technologies that can greatly enhance longevity, cognition, and well-being
the production of an analysis that corresponds too closely or exactly to a particular set of data, and may therefore fail to fit to additional data or predict future observations reliably
something that you do, or a thing that you give someone, that expresses your feelings or intentions, although it might have little practical effect
instances: As a token of our gratitude for all that you have done, we would like you to accept this small gift.

title: El Reino de Dios es como un grano de mostaza
content: many grain legumes are deficient in the sulfur-containing amino acids cystine and methionine

title: El Reino de Dios es como un grano de mostaza
discussion: Muchas cosas grandes empiezan siendo pequeñas
A menudo nos cuesta apreciar la grandeza y consecuencias de algo simple
related-to: kill a revolution in the bud
El Principito obsesionado con arrancar baobabs incipientes

topic: ataques con drones a Rusia en E. de Siberia

definition: consist of two protons and two neutrons bound together into a particle identical to a helium-4 nucleus
a high-energy, high-speed electron or positron emitted by the radioactive decay of an atomic nucleus, known as beta decay
notes: There are two forms of beta decay, β− decay and β+ decay, which produce electrons and positrons, respectively

definition: consists of the shortest wavelength electromagnetic waves, typically shorter than those of X-rays
origin: high energy interactions like the radioactive decay of atomic nuclei
energy: from a few kiloelectronvolts (keV) to approximately 8 megaelectronvolts (MeV), corresponding to the typical energy levels in nuclei with reasonably long lifetimes
notes: The energy ranges of gamma rays and X-rays overlap in the electromagnetic spectrum, so the terminology for these electromagnetic waves varies between scientific disciplines

Gamma rays are ionizing radiation and are thus hazardous to life. They can cause DNA mutations, cancer and tumors, and at high doses burns and radiation sickness. Due to their high penetration power, they can damage bone marrow and internal organs. Unlike alpha and beta rays, they easily pass through the body and thus pose a formidable radiation protection challenge, requiring shielding made from dense materials such as lead or concrete. On Earth, the magnetosphere protects life from most types of lethal cosmic radiation other than gamma rays.

definition: En la ética aplicada, la casuística se refiere al razonamiento basado en casos. Se utiliza en cuestiones éticas y jurídicas, y a menudo representa una crítica del razonamiento basado en principios o reglas. La casuística es utilizar la razón para resolver problemas morales aplicando reglas teóricas a instancias específicas.

name: Core Principles in a Field
author: John Reed
content: When you first study a field, it seems like you have to memorize a zillion things. You don’t. What you need is to identify the three-to-five core principles that govern the field. The million things you thought you had to memorize are various combinations of the core principles.

definition: a numerical or other measurable factor forming one of a set that defines a system or sets the conditions of its operation
an element of a system that is useful, or critical, when identifying the system, or when evaluating its performance, status, condition, etc.

a characteristic that defines or classifies a system, often used to set limits or conditions; it can be a variable in a mathematical equation or a fixed value that influences how something is done or performed.
notes: In statistics, parameters are characteristics of an entire population, such as the average age of teachers in the United States

definition: a milky fermented liquid, largely made from Agave salmiana, Agave mapisaga, and Agave americana sap, which has an herbal aroma, low alcohol content (4–6%), and high acidity (pH = 3.5–4.2)
notes: its origins date back to the Early Classic period (AD 150–650), was used in religious rituals to honor the Aztec goddess, Mayahuel, and was regularly consumed by Aztec nobility

definition: the ultimate source word from which one or more cognates derive
instances: the etymon of both Welsh ceffyl and Irish capall is the Proto-Celtic *kaballos (all meaning horse)

definition: a word inherited across a language barrier, coming from a particular etymon in an ancestor language
instances: Russian мо́ре and Polish morze are both descendants of Proto-Slavic *moře (meaning sea)

definition: any of a set of words that have been inherited in direct descent from an etymological ancestor in a common parent language
notes: because language change can have radical effects on both the sound and the meaning of a word, cognates may not be obvious, and it often takes rigorous study of historical sources and the application of the comparative method to establish whether lexemes are cognate
cognates need not have the same meaning, as they may have undergone semantic change as the languages developed independently

definition: the source of related words within a single language
notes: no language barrier is crossed

definition: the source of related words within a single language
notes: no language barrier is crossed

definition: one of the words which have their source in a root word, and were at some time created from the root word using morphological constructs such as suffixes, prefixes, and slight changes to the vowels or to the consonants of the root word.
notes: no language barrier is crossed

definition: the sense of control that you feel in your life, your capacity to influence your own thoughts and behavior, and have faith in your ability to handle a wide range of tasks and situations. Your sense of agency helps you to be psychologically stable, yet flexible in the face of conflict or change
a reaction that requires energy to be driven
notes: Endergonic means "absorbing energy in the form of work".
The activation energy for the reaction is typically larger than the overall energy of the exergonic reaction (1). Endergonic reactions are nonspontaneous.

author: Neal Stephenson
content: Where serious and competent people need to get things done in the real world, all considerations of tradition and protocol fly out of the window.

author: Neal Stephenson
content: The only thing that can effect a change in personality is something that physically rewires the brain and/or alters the body's chemical milieu.

author: Neal Stephenson
content: The future is there, looking back at us, trying to make sense of the fiction we will have become.

author: Neal Stephenson
content: Any property that is open to common use gets destroyed. Because everyone has incentive to use it to the max, but no one has incentive to maintain.

author: Neal Stephenson
content: Well, all information looks like noise until you break the code.

name: catarsis
definition: f. Purificación, liberación o transformación interior suscitadas por una experiencia vital profunda.

name: ecología profunda
definition: La ecología profunda es una rama de la filosofía ecológica que considera a la humanidad parte de su entorno, proponiendo cambios culturales, políticos, sociales y económicos para lograr una convivencia armónica entre los seres humanos y el resto de los seres vivos.

name: ecología profunda
author: Arne Naess
content: la ecología profunda o de amplio alcance (deep, long-range ecology) se distingue de la ecología superficial o de corto alcance (shallow, short-range ecology) en un cuestionamiento más hondo de las causas y fundamentos de la crisis ecológica. Partiendo del reconocimiento del valor inherente de la diversidad ecológica y cultural de todos los seres vivos, su enfoque no se limita a aquello que pone en peligro el bienestar o la supervivencia de la especie humana. La ecología profunda declara la interdependencia fundamental entre todos los fenómenos y el hecho de que, como individuos y como sociedades, estamos inmersos en (y finalmente dependientes de) los procesos cíclicos de la naturaleza.

title: Ecología profunda controvertida
content: Las posiciones defendidas por la ecología profunda han sido objeto de tantas controversias y críticas que merece la pena indagar en las razones que indujeron, por ejemplo, al cineasta y ecologista de moda, Al Gore, a calificarla como una filosofía “intrínsecamente misántropa” en la que el ser humano es “un alien en la Tierra” [1], o al intelectual francés Luc Ferry a concluir que “se puede decir legítimamente que la ecología profunda hunde algunas de sus raíces en el nazismo y alza sus ramas hasta las esferas más extremas del izquierdismo cultural” [2]. Y observamos que, en casi todos los casos, el pretendido radicalismo de la ecología profunda estriba en su crítica del antropocentrismo y de aquellos fundamentos culturales de Occidente que han abocado al mundo a la crisis multidimensional que enfrenta desde hace tiempo.

name: butoh significa bailar con sombras
content: Todo el mundo tiene sombra. Todo el mundo puede bailar butoh. Coger sombras. Cuantas más sombras.
